findings.title: Users Claim NFTs Without Auction Participation
findings.description: The users have the ability to mint NFTs to their accounts without participating in the auction process by calling the settleCurrentAndCreateNewAuction() function at the end of an auction cycle.

findings.title: Settled Auction Funds Exploit
findings.description: The winning bidder can exploit the funds transfer process by arbitrarily setting `skatePercent` and `daoPercent` values, allowing manipulation of the transfer process.

findings.title: Funds Transfer does not Fallback
findings.description: The `_safeTransferETHWithFallback` implementation does not follow the contract’s description. The function is supposed to transfer ETH. If it fails it should wrap the ETH and try to send it as WETH as a fallback. In the actual implementation, the function solely transfers ETH without fallback.

findings.title: Contract Owner can Drain the Auction Funds
findings.description: The contract owner has the ability to take all the auction's contract balance, potentially causing bidders who lose to not receive their bid amount back and winning amounts not being transferred to Skate and Dao addresses.

findings.title: Contract does not Pause on Failure
findings.description: The contract does not pause when auction creation fails, violating the specification that requires pausing the auction in case of failure.

findings.title: L01 - Public Function could be Declared External
findings.description: Public functions that are never called by the contract should be declared external to save gas.

findings.title: L11 - Unnecessary Boolean equality
findings.description: The comparison to boolean constants is redundant. Boolean constants can be used directly and do not need to be compared to true or false.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Detected missing events for critical arithmetic parameters. There are functions that have no event emitted, so it is difficult to track off-chain changes.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: Solidity defines a naming convention that should be followed.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Variables defined in local scope are not initialized and have same names as upper scoped variables.
